content.name: risk_title_bar
content.content: Risk Management

content.name: risk_management
content.content:
SELF NEGLECT FACTORS
  • Precipitating
    Recent life events/ homelessness/ physical or mental illness.
  • Predisposing
    Poor social skills/ poor dietary habits/ chronic illness/ mental illness/ active symptoms/ hygiene skills/ financial circumstances.
  • Perpetuating
    Negative symptoms/ intellectual diffi culties/ dementia/ substance misuse/ poor or limited accommodation/ poor social support.
  • Protective
    Stable or supported accommodation/ social support/ engagement with mental health team.
VULNERABILITY FACTORS
  • Precipitating: acute mental illness/ exposure to external abusive peer group/ social environment change.
  • Predisposing: mental illness/ learning disabilities/ age/ past history of exploitation/ poor coping, assertiveness and social skills.
  • Perpetuating: inpatient/ in institutional settings/ treatment resistance/ limited assertiveness or social skills.
  • Protective: stable social environment/ good social support structures/ good engagement and monitoring.
ABSCONDING FACTORS
  • Precipitating: stressors eg. tribunal, bad news, relationship/ interpersonal stress/ anniversaries/ known dates of concern/ homesickness.
  • Predisposing: male gender/ young age/ relapse in mental illness/ seasonal issues/ history of absconding/ personality disorder/ history of psychoactive substance use.
  • Perpetuating: age/ male/ perception of being locked away/ being frightened by peers in the ward environment/ cognitive problems resulting in failure to recognise the ward environment.
  • Protective: engagement with clinical team/ social supports/ supportive interpersonal relationships.
SUICIDE FACTORS
  • Precipitating: recent stressor (loss or perceived loss)/ high levels of distress/ recent discharge from hospital/ physical illness.
  • Predisposing: mental illness & PD/family history of suicide/ family history of mental illness/ childhood adversity/living alone/ separated/ widowed/ divorced/ unemployed/ retired + some job groups/ SEC status/ male gender/ Age groups: >65 years, young men (15-30) + middle aged men suffering a loss/ inpatient status/ recurrent suicidal thoughts/ past para-suicidal behaviours and method used/ physical health problems/ recent relapse/ access to means of self harm/ suicide/ chronic sleep problems.
  • Perpetuating: maladaptive coping skills/ negative attitudes/ treatment resistance/ non-compliance/ staffing levels/ shifts as an inpatient/ co-morbidity/ substance misuse/ high impulsivity/ hopelessness/ ambivalence to the future/ cognitive distortions
  • Protective: stable relationship/ good social network and coping mechanisms/ engagement with mental health teams/ compliance with medications/ employment/ religious/ cultural beliefs/ regret at previous attempt(s) of self-harm
VIOLENCE FACTORS
  • Precipitating: dispute/ disagreement/ stressors and other destabilisers/ goal related/ TCO symptoms/ command hallucinations/ suspiciousness/ morbid jealousy/ circumstances or environment change/ loss or perceived loss/ non-compliance.
  • Predisposing: history of mental illness/ history of PD/ psychopathy/ history of violence and criminality/ young age of violence/ substance misuse/ employment problems/ relationship instability/ early maladjustment/ supervision failure/ impulsivity/ anger management and/or executive dysfunction/ exposure to known destabilisers.
  • Perpetuating: poor insight/ negative attitudes/ active relapse/ symptoms of a mental illness/ response to treatment/substance misuse/ unrealistic plans/ criminal peer group/social disadvantage/ access to weapons.
  • Protective: stable relationship/ good social network and coping mechanisms/ engagement with mental health teams/ compliance with medications/ employment/ religious/ cultural beliefs/ remorse/ victim empathy.

content.name: inform_panel
content.content:
SELF HARM/SUICIDE QUESTIONS
  • How do you feel about the future? Does everything seem hopeless?
  • Have you ever felt that life is not worth living?
  • Have you ever acted upon suicidal thoughts before?
  • Method (lethality), mental state, stressors, and wider circumstances at the time â are these similar to now?
  • Do you have any current thoughts of harming yourself now or recently?
  • Do you think you would act upon these thoughts?
SELF HARM/SUICIDE QUESTIONS
  • Why do you feel this way do you think? (i.e. motivations eg. sleep/escape/punish self/others/feeling not worthy/command hallucinations/communicate distress or relieve tensions).
  • Are there particular times or situations that trigger your thoughts/feelings?
  • Is there anything that you would change that would make you feel differently?
  • If you have had suicidal thoughts in the past and not acted upon them: why? What stopped you from acting out on them?
  • What do you think could prevent you from acting on them now?
POST SELF HARM QUESTIONS
  • Why now? Was it a sudden or planned decision?
  • What was happening for you at the time (precipitant)?
  • Did you make any preparations eg. make a will / sort out affairs beforehand?
  • Did you do it when no one else was around?
  • What did you think about when you did it? Did you think about anyone else and how it might affect them?
  • Did you feel relieved that you survived?
  • What has changed? What can be changed?
VIOLENCE QUESTIONS
  • Have you been stressed recently? (details) Has anyone upset you recently?
  • Have you ever had thoughts of hurting anyone? (plus details)
  • If you wanted to hurt someone how would you do it?
  • Do you carry weapons / make weapons for this or any other reason?
  • Have you ever thought about killing someone?
  • Do you have thoughts of hurting or killing someone now?
  • How often do you think about it?
  • Are these thoughts triggered by situations / times or events?
VIOLENCE QUESTIONS
  • Have you ever acted upon these thoughts? (plus details)
  • Whatâs your explanation on why you have these thoughts? (and explore motivation)
  • How would violence help you, with your problems?
  • What stops you from acting upon these thoughts?
  • Do you have any current plans?
  • What do you think about ______ situation? (Referring to a recent media portrayal of a homicide.)

content.content:
Pocket Ps App
Pocket Ps and Mental Health Guidelines

Devised by Dr Jaspreet S Phull
Consultant Forensic Psychiatrist
Start
By using this app, you agree to the Terms & Conditions, Cookie Police and Privacy Policy

content.name: risks_title_bar
content.content: Risk Events Monitoring

content.name: risks
content.content:
RISK EVENTS MONITORING
  • Risk assessment and formulation are dependent on both static and dynamic (stable and acute) factors, and thus should be viewed as a dynamic process.
  • Thus, a live document listing risk events (i.e. events that could trigger a reassessment of risk) should be created and maintained to ensure monitoring and adaptation of risk formulation and management.

content.name: risk_management
content.content:
Five Ps Risk Formulation
Predisposing
S usceptibility
Precipitating
T rigger
Perpetuating
O ngoing
Protective
P reventing
Predisposing factors
↑
Precipitating factors ← Problem → Prepetuating factors
↓
Protecting factors

content.name: bipolar_title_bar
content.content: Bipolar Disorder

content.name: item_3284639
content.content: Assessment

content.name: item_de736dd4
content.content: Treatment

content.name: item_8597e77f
content.content: Transition

content.name: bipolar_assessment
content.content:
• Clear purpose, care pathway goals, estimated discharge date are set consistent with crisis plans and overall formulations.
  • Patients are admitted with shared goals via review with patient, clinical team, notes and carers.
  • Precipitants to relapse and perpetuating stresses are considered.
  • Involve advocacy and offer second opinion if requested.
  • Admission reserved for more complex and severe depressive conditions associated with significant risks.
  • Consider rehabilitation and create a physical health plan.
  • Mood rating scale (e.g. Young's mania rating scale etc.) and provide psychoeducation.
•    Document a thorough history
  • Family history.
  • Review of previous episodes.
  • Symptoms now & between episodes.
  • Triggers.
  • Substance misuse.
  • Anxiety.
  • Physical health.
  • Differential diagnosis.
  • Psychosocial stressors.

content.name: bipolar_treatment
content.content:
• Provide information on ward, diagnosis and treatment.
  • Regular 1:1 contact with key worker, medics and access to pharmacy.
  • Meaningful activity and dietary care interventions.
  • Continuity of care with care coordinator.
  • Patient views considered- access to advocacy and support Medication Monitoring.
Acute Mania
  • Stop/reduce antidepressant.
  • Add antipsychotic â haloperidol/ olanzapine/ quetiapine/ risperi done.
  • An alternative antipsychotic then a mood stabiliser (lithium then valproate) with optimisation of dosing. Consider benzodiazepines.
  • Manage insomnia.
  • Note â interactions, co morbidities, effects of anticholinergic load, choice, if stoppingreduce meds over 4/52.
  • ECT âreserved for either severe mania or catatonia.
Prophylaxis of Mania
  • Lithium.
  • Valproate.
  • Olanzapine.
  • Quetiapine.
  • Relapse prevention treatments.
Bipolar Depression
  • Increase anti manic medication.
  • Quetiapine as monotherapy.
  • SSRIs (+ gastro protection if reqd) co prescribed with olanzapine.
  • Psychological treatments.
  • Lithium optimisation.
  • ECT if severe.
  • Lithium augmentation with olanzapine or lamotrigine.
Prophylaxis for Bipolar Depression
  • Long term minimal dose SSRI + mood stabiliser.
  • CBT in combination.
  • Quetiapine + Lamotrigine.
  • Relapse Prevention.
Long Term Management For Rapid Cycling
  • Lithium + Valproate.
  • Or Lithium on its own.
General Management
  • Regular activity.
  • Environment needs.
  • Coping strategies development.
  • Offer supported activities.
  • Education.
  • Employment.
  • Document activity in care plans and occupational outcomes.
  • Promote healthy lifestyle â QRISK2/QDSCORE.
Medication Monitoring
  • Lithium â kidney function and levels, risk of rebound with poor adherence, plasma levels after 1/52 + same after dose increase and 3-6/12, advice re toxicity (neurotoxicity, including paraesthesia, ataxia, tremor and cognitive impairment), NSAIDS/ACEi/diuretics, blood monitoring â discontinue if needed over 1-3/12.
  • Valproate â Contraception advice, live function.
  • Quetiapine â Lipids and thyroid function.
  • Lamotrigine â rash.
  • Carbamazepine â liver function, interactions and levels.

content.name: bipolar_transition
content.content:
• Managed endings through setting of early discharge date, key worker and links with carers and community teams.
  • Medication self management and safe leave tested.
  • Safe discharge and leave protocol utilised.
  • Aftercare arrangements (including potential CTO/guardianship etc), WRAP, EWS and crisis plans are reviewed.

content.name: risk_title_bar
content.content: Risk Management Plans

content.name: plan_management
content.content:
RISK MANAGEMENT PLANS
What to include in your Risk Management Plans:
  • Treatment interventions - intended to limit risk factors or enhace protective factors.
  • Supervision - implementation of restrcitions to relevant risk factors e.g. supervision or surveillance strategies couple to be implemented to manage the risk of violence to others.
  • Review - identification of early warning signs or indicators and ongoing review or dynamic risk factors. What events, occurrencies or circumstances might increase this person's risk.
RISK MANAGEMENT PLANNING
  • Victim safety planning - guidance realting past/future potential victims/ interagency planning.
  • Crisis & contingency/ staying well planned - what events, occurrences, or circumstances migh increase this person's risk? What are the early warning signs.
  • Safety & inter-agency planning - guidenace relating past future. possible victims/ inter-agency planning.
  • Crisis contingency plans

content.name: html_3
content.content:
SUMMARY STATEMENTS
  • Mr. X is at risk of ___ (what) to ___ (whom) [problem]. This risk can be precipitated when ___ and other predisposing factors include___, and perpetuating risk factors include ___.
  • Protective factors or interventions that reduce the specified risk include ___. Using the risk matrix provided, it is likely that the severity of the risk is (low/medium/high) because of (describe impact event). It is likely that the frequency of the event will be (low/ medium/high) based on ___.
  • At this time the current risk is (increased/reduced/stable). EWS of the current risk are___ to support Mr/Ms X the risk management plan includes :____.
INTERVENTIONS
  • Immediate (1-7 days): hospital admission, increase in ward security level, obs, short term medication, de-escalation, development of a therapeutic relationship, seclusion, frequency of visits, safeguarding and police involvement.
  • Intermediate (7-28 days): increase social/familial support, 7 day follow up, short-term psychological intervention, other services, development of crisis contingency plans and early warning signs.
  • Longer term (28+ days): substance misuse, emotional regulation, ETS, anger management, supported accommodation, peer group change/ improving a social network, day structure, education, health promotion, social skills, longer term psychological intervention, psycho-education, supervised discharge and employment.
CRISIS CONTINGENCY PLANS
  • Early warning signs identification.
  • Contact (named) individual & their details.
  • Past strategies used to manage crises.
  • Level of security required when obtaining a hospital.
  • Out of hours contact numbers.
  • Identification of a GP & primary healthcare team.
  • Creation of a current crisis plan (ideally with âtieredâ levels).
  • Record of any unmet needs, disagreements and missing information.
